description: Evidence-based clinical guidelines for lung nodule management and imaging appropriateness

entries.title: Fleischner Society Guidelines - Solid Nodules in Low-Risk Patients
entries.content:
Management of incidental solid pulmonary nodules in LOW-RISK patients (minimal/no smoking history, no other risk factors):

<6mm: No routine follow-up recommended
6-8mm: CT at 6-12 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months
>8mm: Consider CT at 3 months, PET/CT, or tissue sampling

Risk factors include: smoking history, family history of lung cancer, upper lobe location, spiculated margins, emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis.

entries.title: Fleischner Society Guidelines - Solid Nodules in High-Risk Patients
entries.content:
Management of incidental solid pulmonary nodules in HIGH-RISK patients (heavy smoking history, other risk factors present):

<6mm: Optional CT at 12 months
6-8mm: CT at 6-12 months, then CT at 18-24 months
>8mm: Consider CT at 3 months, PET/CT, or tissue sampling

High-risk criteria: >30 pack-year smoking history, asbestos/radon exposure, family history (first-degree relative), upper lobe predominant emphysema.

entries.title: Fleischner Society Guidelines - Subsolid Nodules (GGN)
entries.content:
Management of incidental PURE GROUND-GLASS NODULES (pGGN):

<6mm: No routine follow-up
>=6mm: CT at 6-12 months to confirm persistence, then CT every 2 years until 5 years

Persistent pGGN >=6mm with solid component: Increased risk of adenocarcinoma. Consider PET/CT or biopsy if solid component develops or grows.

entries.title: Fleischner Society Guidelines - Part-Solid Nodules
entries.content:
Management of incidental PART-SOLID NODULES (mixed GGO + solid):

<6mm overall: No routine follow-up (rare, usually benign)
>=6mm overall: CT at 3-6 months to confirm persistence

Persistent part-solid nodules with solid component <6mm: Annual CT for 5 years
Persistent part-solid nodules with solid component >=6mm: PET/CT, biopsy, or surgical resection recommended

Part-solid nodules have HIGHEST malignancy risk of all nodule types. Solid component size is key prognostic factor.

entries.title: Fleischner Society - Multiple Nodules Management
entries.content:
Management of MULTIPLE pulmonary nodules:

Primary approach: Manage based on the MOST SUSPICIOUS nodule

<6mm dominant nodule: CT at 3-6 months (shorter interval than solitary)
>=6mm dominant nodule: CT at 3-6 months, then based on stability

Considerations:
- Multiple nodules suggest infection or metastases more than primary lung cancer
- Unilateral distribution more concerning than bilateral
- History of extrathoracic malignancy raises suspicion for metastases
- Miliary pattern (<3mm, countless) suggests hematogenous spread

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category 1 - Negative
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category 1 - NEGATIVE:

Definition: No lung nodules OR nodules with specific benite features

Benign features include:
- Complete calcification (diffuse, central, popcorn, laminated)
- Fat attenuation (<-40 HU) - diagnostic of hamartoma
- Perifissural nodules (PFN) meeting strict criteria

Management: Continue annual screening (if screening population)
Malignancy probability: <1%

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category 2 - Benign Appearance
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category 2 - BENIGN APPEARANCE:

Criteria:
- Solid nodule: <6mm (new or stable)
- Part-solid nodule: <6mm total diameter (new or stable)
- Pure GGN: <30mm (new or stable at any size)
- Category 3-4 nodules stable >=3 months

Management: Continue annual screening
Malignancy probability: <1%

Note: Size threshold 6mm applies to average diameter [(length + width)/2]

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category 3 - Probably Benign
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category 3 - PROBABLY BENIGN:

Criteria:
- Solid nodule: >=6mm to <8mm (new) OR >=6mm to <15mm (stable/growing slowly)
- Part-solid: >=6mm total with solid <6mm (new or stable)
- Pure GGN: >=30mm (new) OR any size with new solid component

Management: 6-month LDCT
Malignancy probability: 1-2%

Key: Short-term follow-up to assess growth/stability

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category 4A - Suspicious
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category 4A - SUSPICIOUS:

Criteria:
- Solid nodule: >=8mm to <15mm (new or growing)
- Part-solid: >=6mm total with solid >=6mm to <8mm (new or growing solid)
- Endobronchial nodule

Management: 3-month LDCT; PET/CT may be used if >=8mm solid
Malignancy probability: 5-15%

Considerations: Growth = increase >=1.5mm in any dimension

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category 4B - Very Suspicious
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category 4B - VERY SUSPICIOUS:

Criteria:
- Solid nodule: >=15mm (new or growing)
- Part-solid: solid component >=8mm (new or growing)
- Category 3/4 nodule with significant growth (<15mm increasing >=1.5mm)

Management: Chest CT with/without contrast, PET/CT, tissue sampling, or multidisciplinary consultation
Malignancy probability: >15%

Immediate action recommended due to high malignancy risk

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category 4X - Additional Features
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category 4X - SUSPICIOUS WITH ADDITIONAL FEATURES:

This modifier indicates Category 3-4 nodules with additional suspicious features warranting upgrade:

Suspicious features:
- Spiculated margins
- Upper lobe location
- Rapid doubling time (<400 days)
- Lymphadenopathy
- Known primary malignancy (potential metastasis)
- Pleural effusion
- Chest wall invasion

Management: Escalate to more aggressive workup than baseline category
Clinical judgment essential

metadata.management: Escalated workup based on clinical context

entries.title: Lung-RADS Category S - Other/Incidental Findings
entries.content:
Lung-RADS Category S - OTHER CLINICALLY SIGNIFICANT FINDINGS:

Incidental findings requiring attention:
- Coronary artery calcification (CAC score correlation)
- Aortic aneurysm (>4cm ascending, >5cm descending)
- Pulmonary embolism
- Emphysema (quantification)
- Interstitial lung disease
- Significant lymphadenopathy
- Adrenal nodules
- Vertebral compression fractures
- Breast abnormalities
- Thyroid nodules

Management: Additional workup/referral as clinically indicated
Not a replacement for routine clinical care

entries.title: ACR Appropriateness - Solitary Pulmonary Nodule Workup
entries.content:
ACR Appropriateness Criteria for Solitary Pulmonary Nodule:

Low probability of malignancy (<5%):
- CT follow-up: Usually Appropriate
- PET/CT: May Be Appropriate
- Biopsy: Usually Not Appropriate

Intermediate probability (5-65%):
- PET/CT: Usually Appropriate
- CT-guided biopsy: Usually Appropriate
- CT follow-up: May Be Appropriate

High probability (>65%):
- PET/CT staging: Usually Appropriate
- Surgical resection: Usually Appropriate (if operable)
- CT-guided biopsy: May Be Appropriate (if diagnosis needed)

Probability calculators: Mayo Clinic model, Brock model, VA model

entries.title: ACR Appropriateness - Chest Pain Evaluation
entries.content:
ACR Appropriateness Criteria for Acute Chest Pain - Suspected Pulmonary Embolism:

High clinical probability (Wells >4 or positive D-dimer):
- CT Pulmonary Angiography: Usually Appropriate (first-line)
- V/Q Scan: Usually Appropriate (if CT contraindicated)
- MR Angiography: May Be Appropriate (limited evidence)

Low clinical probability (Wells <=4):
- D-dimer first: Usually Appropriate
- CT PA without D-dimer: Usually Not Appropriate

Pregnancy considerations:
- CXR first, then V/Q if normal CXR
- CT PA acceptable if V/Q unavailable
- MRA emerging option

Contrast allergy: V/Q scan or MRA preferred

entries.title: ACR Appropriateness - ILD Evaluation
entries.content:
ACR Appropriateness Criteria for Chronic Dyspnea - Suspected ILD:

Initial evaluation:
- Chest radiograph: Usually Appropriate (first-line screening)
- HRCT chest without contrast: Usually Appropriate (diagnostic)
- Chest CT with contrast: May Be Appropriate (if vascular concern)

HRCT technique requirements:
- Thin sections (<=1.25mm)
- Prone imaging (to exclude dependent atelectasis)
- Expiratory images (air trapping assessment)
- No IV contrast needed for parenchymal assessment

Follow-up:
- Serial HRCT for disease progression monitoring
- Interval based on clinical course (3-12 months)
- Quantitative CT emerging for objective assessment

entries.title: ACR Appropriateness - Lung Cancer Staging
entries.content:
ACR Appropriateness Criteria for Non-small Cell Lung Cancer Staging:

Initial staging:
- PET/CT whole body: Usually Appropriate (most accurate for M staging)
- Contrast-enhanced CT chest/abdomen: Usually Appropriate
- Brain MRI with contrast: Usually Appropriate (especially for stage III-IV)

Mediastinal staging:
- PET/CT positive nodes: Tissue confirmation recommended
- EBUS/EUS: Usually Appropriate for accessible nodes
- Mediastinoscopy: Gold standard if minimally invasive fails

Adrenal characterization:
- Chemical shift MRI: Usually Appropriate for indeterminate adrenal
- PET/CT: Usually Appropriate
- Adrenal biopsy: May Be Appropriate if needed for staging

Bone metastases:
- PET/CT: Usually Appropriate
- Bone scan: May Be Appropriate if PET unavailable

entries.title: British Thoracic Society - Pleural Effusion Guidelines
entries.content:
BTS Guidelines for Investigation of Unilateral Pleural Effusion:

Initial assessment:
- Clinical history + CXR
- Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis (not blind)
- Light's criteria to differentiate exudate vs transudate

Light's Criteria (exudate if ANY ONE met):
- Pleural protein/serum protein >0.5
- Pleural LDH/serum LDH >0.6
- Pleural LDH >2/3 upper limit of normal serum LDH

Fluid analysis:
- Cell count and differential (lymphocyte-predominant = TB, malignancy)
- Cytology (minimum 20mL, repeat if negative)
- pH (<7.2 suggests complicated parapneumonic/empyema)
- Glucose (<60mg/dL = rheumatoid, empyema, malignancy)
- Adenosine deaminase (>40 U/L suggests TB)

Imaging:
- CT with contrast: Pleural thickening, enhancement, nodularity suggest malignancy
- PET/CT: May help identify occult primary

entries.title: GOLD Guidelines - COPD Classification
entries.content:
GOLD 2023 COPD Classification:

Spirometric classification (post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC <0.70):
- GOLD 1 (Mild): FEV1 >=80% predicted
- GOLD 2 (Moderate): 50% <= FEV1 <80% predicted
- GOLD 3 (Severe): 30% <= FEV1 <50% predicted
- GOLD 4 (Very Severe): FEV1 <30% predicted

ABE Assessment (replaces ABCD):
- Group A: Low symptoms (mMRC 0-1, CAT <10), 0-1 exacerbations
- Group B: High symptoms (mMRC >=2, CAT >=10), 0-1 exacerbations
- Group E: >=2 moderate exacerbations OR >=1 hospitalization (regardless of symptoms)

CT findings in COPD:
- Emphysema quantification (%LAA-950)
- Airway wall thickening (Pi10)
- Pulmonary artery enlargement (PA:Ao ratio >1)
- Bronchiectasis

entries.title: ATS/ERS - IPF Diagnostic Criteria
entries.content:
ATS/ERS/JRS/ALAT Guidelines for IPF Diagnosis:

UIP pattern on HRCT (all 4 required):
1. Basal and subpleural predominance
2. Honeycombing with/without traction bronchiectasis
3. Absence of features inconsistent with UIP

Probable UIP on HRCT (lacks honeycombing):
- Basal, subpleural reticulation
- Traction bronchiectasis
- No features inconsistent with UIP

Features inconsistent with UIP:
- Upper/mid-lung predominance
- Peribronchovascular predominance
- Extensive ground-glass (more than reticulation)
- Micronodules, cysts, mosaic attenuation
- Consolidation (excluding acute exacerbation)

Diagnosis:
- Definite UIP on HRCT: IPF diagnosis likely without biopsy
- Probable/Indeterminate: Consider surgical lung biopsy
- MDD (multidisciplinary discussion): Essential for diagnosis

entries.title: Nodule Volume Doubling Time Assessment
entries.content:
Volume Doubling Time (VDT) in Lung Nodule Assessment:

VDT calculation:
VDT = (t2 - t1) × ln(2) / ln(V2/V1)
Where t = time, V = volume

Malignancy probability by VDT:
- <20 days: Usually benign (likely inflammatory)
- 20-400 days: Suspicious for malignancy
- 400-600 days: Intermediate (includes slow-growing adenocarcinoma)
- >600 days: Usually benign (granuloma, hamartoma)

Volumetry advantages over 2D:
- More sensitive to small changes
- Detects 25% volume change (= 9% diameter change)
- Computer-assisted reduces measurement variability

Lung-RADS 2022 VDT considerations:
- <6mm nodules: Consider volumetry for accurate surveillance
- Software requirements: Standardized protocols needed
- Inter-scan variability: ~25% for same-day scans

entries.title: Perifissural Nodule Criteria
entries.content:
Criteria for Perifissural Nodules (PFN) - Likely Intrapulmonary Lymph Nodes:

Classic PFN features:
1. Attached to fissure OR within 15mm of fissure
2. Solid, homogeneous
3. Smooth margins
4. Oval/lentiform/triangular shape
5. <10mm in longest diameter

Typical vs Atypical PFN:
- Typical: All classic features, VDT not applicable
- Atypical: >=1 atypical feature (round, >10mm)

Management (per Lung-RADS 2022):
- Typical PFN: Category 2 (benign), no follow-up needed
- Atypical PFN: Manage per size criteria

Caveats:
- Not ALL fissural nodules are benign
- Spiculated margins warrant standard nodule management
- Prior malignancy: Consider metastasis regardless of location

entries.title: TNM Staging - Lung Cancer 8th Edition
entries.content:
TNM Staging for Lung Cancer (8th Edition, AJCC/UICC):

T (Primary Tumor):
- T1a: <=1cm
- T1b: >1-2cm
- T1c: >2-3cm
- T2a: >3-4cm OR involvement of main bronchus (not carina), visceral pleura, atelectasis
- T2b: >4-5cm
- T3: >5-7cm OR chest wall/pericardium/phrenic nerve invasion, separate nodule same lobe
- T4: >7cm OR diaphragm/mediastinum/heart/great vessels/trachea/carina/esophagus/vertebra, separate nodule different ipsilateral lobe

N (Regional Nodes):
- N0: No nodal metastasis
- N1: Ipsilateral peribronchial/hilar
- N2: Ipsilateral mediastinal/subcarinal
- N3: Contralateral or supraclavicular

M (Distant Metastasis):
- M0: No distant metastasis
- M1a: Contralateral lung nodule, pleural/pericardial effusion
- M1b: Single extrathoracic metastasis
- M1c: Multiple extrathoracic metastases

entries.title: Mediastinal Lymph Node Stations
entries.content:
IASLC Mediastinal Lymph Node Map (8th Edition):

Supraclavicular zone:
- 1: Low cervical, supraclavicular, sternal notch

Superior mediastinal:
- 2R/2L: Upper paratracheal (above aortic arch)
- 3a: Prevascular
- 3p: Retrotracheal
- 4R/4L: Lower paratracheal

Aortic:
- 5: Subaortic (AP window)
- 6: Para-aortic (ascending aorta)

Inferior mediastinal:
- 7: Subcarinal
- 8: Paraesophageal
- 9: Pulmonary ligament

Hilar/Interlobar:
- 10: Hilar
- 11: Interlobar

Peripheral:
- 12: Lobar
- 13: Segmental
- 14: Subsegmental

Size criteria: Short axis >1cm suggests abnormal (sensitivity ~60%)
PET/CT: SUVmax >2.5 suggests malignancy (specificity ~80%)

entries.title: COVID-19 CT Classification (CO-RADS)
entries.content:
CO-RADS Classification for COVID-19 Pneumonia:

CO-RADS 1: Very low suspicion
- Normal CT OR non-infectious findings

CO-RADS 2: Low suspicion
- Findings consistent with other infection (bronchiolitis, lobar pneumonia, abscess)

CO-RADS 3: Indeterminate
- Features compatible with COVID-19 but also other diseases
- Perihilar ground-glass, homogeneous patterns

CO-RADS 4: High suspicion
- Typical features but not pathognomonic
- Unilateral GGO, multifocal but not peripheral

CO-RADS 5: Very high suspicion
- Typical COVID-19 features:
  * Bilateral, peripheral, basal predominant GGO
  * Crazy-paving pattern
  * Consolidation in later stages
  * Subpleural bands
  * Vascular thickening within GGO

CO-RADS 6: PCR-confirmed COVID-19

entries.title: Pneumonia Severity Assessment (CURB-65 + CT)
entries.content:
Pneumonia Severity Assessment:

CURB-65 Score:
- Confusion: 1 point
- Urea >7 mmol/L: 1 point
- Respiratory rate >=30: 1 point
- Blood pressure <90 systolic or <=60 diastolic: 1 point
- Age >=65: 1 point

Management by score:
- 0-1: Outpatient management
- 2: Hospital admission consider
- 3-5: ICU admission consider

CT Severity Indicators:
- Extent of consolidation (>50% = severe)
- Bilateral involvement
- Pleural effusion (parapneumonic)
- Cavitation (suggests necrotizing pneumonia)
- Pulmonary artery enlargement (suggests strain)

CT vs CXR:
- CT more sensitive for early pneumonia
- CT better for complication detection
- CXR sufficient for uncomplicated CAP

entries.title: Pulmonary Embolism CT Severity (RV/LV Ratio)
entries.content:
CT Pulmonary Angiography Severity Assessment:

RV/LV Ratio:
- Measured at widest transverse diameter
- Four-chamber view on axial images
- RV/LV >1.0: Suggests right heart strain
- RV/LV >1.5: Severe dysfunction

CT signs of RV dysfunction:
- RV dilatation (>1:1 RV:LV ratio)
- Interventricular septal bowing toward LV
- Contrast reflux into IVC/hepatic veins
- PA enlargement (>29mm main PA)

Clot Burden Assessment:
- Central (saddle, main PA): Most severe
- Lobar: Moderate-severe
- Segmental: Moderate
- Subsegmental: Often incidental, clinical significance varies

Quantitative Obstruction Index:
- Qanadli score: Percentage obstruction
- >40% obstruction correlates with RV dysfunction

Management implications:
- RV dysfunction + hemodynamic instability: Thrombolysis/thrombectomy
- RV dysfunction + stable: Close monitoring, anticoagulation

entries.title: Thoracic Aortic Measurements
entries.content:
Normal Thoracic Aortic Dimensions and Thresholds:

Normal diameter (varies by age, gender, BSA):
- Aortic root: 2.1-3.5cm
- Ascending aorta: 2.1-3.4cm
- Aortic arch: 2.0-3.0cm
- Descending thoracic: 1.6-2.6cm

Aneurysm thresholds:
- Ascending: >4.0cm (surgical consideration at 5.5cm)
- Descending: >4.0cm (surgical consideration at 6.0cm)
- Bicuspid aortic valve: Lower surgical threshold (5.0cm ascending)

Measurement technique:
- Perpendicular to long axis (double-oblique MPR)
- Outer wall to outer wall
- Gated CT preferred for aortic root

Growth monitoring:
- >3mm/year: Concerning growth rate
- Annual CT for 4-5cm aneurysms
- Semi-annual for approaching surgical threshold

entries.title: Cardiac CT - CAC Scoring
entries.content:
Coronary Artery Calcium (CAC) Scoring:

Agatston Score calculation:
- CT without contrast, ECG-gated
- Score = Area (mm2) × Density factor (1-4 based on HU)
- Sum all coronary territories

Score interpretation:
- 0: No identifiable plaque (very low risk)
- 1-10: Minimal plaque
- 11-100: Mild plaque
- 101-400: Moderate plaque
- >400: Severe plaque (high risk)

Percentile ranking:
- Important to compare to age/sex matched cohort
- >75th percentile: Increased risk regardless of absolute score

Clinical utility:
- Risk reclassification for intermediate-risk patients
- NOT useful if already known CAD or very high-risk
- Zero CAC associated with very low 10-year event rate (<1%)

Incidental on lung CT:
- Qualitative assessment valuable
- Visual estimate: None, mild, moderate, severe
- Consider formal CAC if significant

entries.title: RECIST 1.1 - Tumor Response Criteria
entries.content:
RECIST 1.1 Criteria for Tumor Response Assessment:

Target lesions:
- Maximum 5 total (2 per organ)
- Measurable: >=10mm (long axis) or >=15mm (short axis for nodes)
- Measure longest diameter (short axis for nodes)

Response categories:
- Complete Response (CR): Disappearance of all target lesions, nodes <10mm
- Partial Response (PR): >=30% decrease in sum of diameters
- Progressive Disease (PD): >=20% increase in sum + >=5mm absolute increase, OR new lesions
- Stable Disease (SD): Neither PR nor PD criteria met

Non-target lesions:
- Qualitative assessment (present, absent, unequivocal progression)

New lesion considerations:
- Must be unequivocal malignant
- <10mm new nodules: Repeat imaging before calling PD
- FDG-avid new lesion on PET confirms progression

Best overall response:
- Must be confirmed by repeat imaging (minimum 4 weeks)

entries.title: iRECIST - Immunotherapy Response
entries.content:
iRECIST Criteria for Immunotherapy Response:

Principle: Accounts for pseudoprogression (tumor flare before response)

Unconfirmed progression (iUPD):
- First progression per RECIST 1.1 criteria
- Continue treatment at investigator discretion
- Repeat imaging at 4-8 weeks

Confirmed progression (iCPD):
- Further increase in tumor burden from iUPD
- Or new lesions after iUPD
- Or worsening non-target disease

Response after iUPD:
- If tumor subsequently decreases: Back to SD/PR/CR
- Pseudoprogression rate: 5-10% depending on tumor type

iCR, iPR, iSD:
- Same as RECIST 1.1 CR, PR, SD
- iCR/iPR require confirmation at >=4 weeks

Clinical considerations:
- Maintain treatment through iUPD if clinically stable
- Clinical deterioration = true progression regardless of imaging

entries.title: Thymic Epithelial Tumor Classification (WHO)
entries.content:
WHO Classification of Thymic Epithelial Tumors:

Thymomas:
- Type A: Spindle/oval cells, rare lymphocytes
- Type AB: Mixed type A areas with lymphocyte-rich areas
- Type B1: Lymphocyte-rich, resembles normal thymus
- Type B2: Scattered epithelial cells among lymphocytes
- Type B3: Predominantly epithelial, few lymphocytes

Thymic carcinoma:
- Squamous cell carcinoma (most common)
- Lymphoepithelioma-like
- Clear cell carcinoma
- Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

CT features suggesting malignancy:
- Irregular/lobulated contours
- Heterogeneous enhancement
- Necrosis, calcification (variable)
- Invasion of adjacent structures
- Pleural/pericardial nodules (drop metastases)

Masaoka staging:
- Stage I: Encapsulated
- Stage II: Microscopic (IIA) or gross (IIB) capsular invasion
- Stage III: Invasion of adjacent organs
- Stage IV: Pleural/pericardial dissemination (IVA) or distant metastases (IVB)

entries.title: Mediastinal Mass - Anterior Compartment DDx
entries.content:
Anterior Mediastinal Mass Differential Diagnosis (4 T's):

Thymic lesions:
- Thymoma (most common anterior mediastinal tumor in adults)
- Thymic carcinoma
- Thymic cyst
- Thymic hyperplasia (rebound after chemotherapy)

Teratoma/Germ cell tumors:
- Mature teratoma (fat, fluid, calcium = diagnostic)
- Seminoma (homogeneous, young males)
- Non-seminomatous GCT (heterogeneous, AFP/beta-hCG elevated)

Terrible lymphoma:
- Hodgkin lymphoma (most common, young adults)
- Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (older adults)
- Prevascular distribution, may encase vessels without invading

Thyroid (substernal goiter):
- Continuous with cervical thyroid
- Displaces trachea, may narrow
- Calcification, cystic areas, avid iodine uptake

Other:
- Parathyroid adenoma (rare in mediastinum)
- Lipoma (fat attenuation diagnostic)
- Morgagni hernia (contains bowel/omentum)

entries.title: Bronchiectasis Severity Assessment
entries.content:
Bronchiectasis Severity Assessment on CT:

Reiff Score (modified):
- 0: No bronchiectasis
- 1: Tubular bronchiectasis (broncho-arterial ratio 1-1.5)
- 2: Varicose bronchiectasis (beaded appearance)
- 3: Cystic/saccular bronchiectasis (>3x artery diameter)

Bhalla Score (comprehensive):
- Severity of bronchiectasis (0-3)
- Peribronchial thickening (0-3)
- Extent of bronchiectasis by lobes
- Mucus plugging extent
- Sacculations/abscesses
- Bullae
- Emphysema
- Collapse/consolidation

BSI (Bronchiectasis Severity Index):
- Incorporates clinical (BMI, FEV1, exacerbations) and radiological variables
- Predicts mortality and exacerbation risk

CT indications for treatment escalation:
- New lobar involvement
- Progression from tubular to cystic
- Increased mucus plugging
- New tree-in-bud (suggests active infection)

entries.title: Emphysema Quantification on CT
entries.content:
Emphysema Quantification on CT:

Visual scoring:
- Grade 0: No emphysema
- Grade 1: <5% parenchymal destruction
- Grade 2: 5-25% destruction
- Grade 3: 25-50% destruction
- Grade 4: 50-75% destruction
- Grade 5: >75% destruction

Quantitative CT (densitometry):
- %LAA-950: Percentage of lung <-950 HU (inspiratory)
- %LAA-856: Percentage <-856 HU (expiratory, gas trapping)
- Percentile method: 15th percentile density (PD15)

Emphysema subtypes:
- Centrilobular: Upper lobe predominant, smoking-related
- Panlobular: Lower lobe predominant, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
- Paraseptal: Subpleural, associated with bullae

Clinical correlations:
- %LAA-950 >15%: Significant emphysema
- Strong correlation with DLCO impairment
- Predicts surgical outcomes (LVRS candidate selection)
- ECLIPSE study cutoffs widely used

entries.title: Sarcoidosis Staging (Chest CT)
entries.content:
Sarcoidosis Staging (Scadding Classification + CT refinement):

Stage 0:
- Normal chest imaging
- Extrathoracic sarcoidosis only

Stage I:
- Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (BHL) only
- Symmetric, non-necrotic nodes
- CT: Calcification in chronic disease

Stage II:
- BHL + parenchymal infiltrates
- CT: Perilymphatic nodules (fissures, bronchovascular bundles)
- Upper/mid lung predominance

Stage III:
- Parenchymal infiltrates WITHOUT BHL
- Nodes may have resolved
- CT: Consolidation, ground-glass, fibrotic changes

Stage IV:
- Pulmonary fibrosis
- Upper lobe volume loss
- Hilar retraction ("shifted hilum" sign)
- Honeycombing, traction bronchiectasis

Prognostic implications:
- Stage I: 60-80% spontaneous resolution
- Stage II: 50-60% resolution
- Stage III: 30% resolution
- Stage IV: Irreversible

entries.title: CT Reporting Standards (ACR)
entries.content:
ACR Guidelines for Structured Chest CT Reporting:

Essential elements:
1. Clinical indication/question
2. Technique (contrast, phases, comparison studies)
3. Findings organized by organ system
4. Impression/Summary (addressing clinical question)

Lung findings structure:
- Airways (trachea, bronchi)
- Parenchyma (nodules, opacities, ILD patterns)
- Pleura (effusions, thickening, pneumothorax)

Mediastinal findings:
- Lymph nodes (size, location, character)
- Vascular (aorta, PA, cardiac chambers)
- Other structures (thymus, esophagus)

Incidental findings:
- Clinically significant findings requiring action
- Modifiers for recommendations (urgent, routine)
- Reference to appropriate guidelines (Fleischner, ACR)

Reporting style:
- Clear, concise language
- Avoid ambiguous terms ("cannot exclude")
- Provide specific measurements
- Likelihood language when appropriate (likely, suspicious for)
